Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterization of a Bioluminescence Reporter System for Mechanical Stress
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, the PIs will investigate the relationship between mechanical properties of the cell and physiological response, using bioluminescence as a fast reporter of mechanosensitivity. Specific questions to be addressed are: (1) What are the mechanical properties of the cell? (2) How is mechanosensitivity related to the mechanical properties of the cell? and (3) What is the role of the cytoskeleton in determining the mechanical properties of cells and their physiological sensitivity? These issues will be studied in three species of dinoflagellates using atomic force microscopy to measure the elasticity of living cells and apply quantified mechanical stress to cells, microfluidics to subject cells to known levels of fluid shear stress, and laser confocal microscopy coupled with fluorescent probes to visualize the cytoskeleton. Pharmacological treatments that disrupt the cytoskeleton will be examined for their effect on cell elasticity and mechanosensitivity. This collaborative project applies advanced methods of physics, material science, and microfluidic technology to characterize the mechanical properties of the cell and the relationship to physiological sensitivity. The goal of the project is to enhance the value of dinoflagellate bioluminescence as a reporter of mechanical stress for applications in both the biological and physical sciences. This project will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups and advances discovery and understanding by providing internship opportunities to these undergraduate students through UCSD internship programs, the opportunity for a Ph.D. graduate student in the physical sciences to work in an interdisciplinary setting, and for two undergraduate students to participate as REU interns. The project advances discovery and understanding by contributing to the professional development of middle and high school science teachers by developing course materials through the Scripps Classroom Connection Summer Institute in partnership with COSEE CA, and providing demonstration kits of dinoflagellate bioluminescence to their students. Project results will be broadly disseminated through established scientific venues as well as education and public outreach activities through the Birch Aquarium at Scripps.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eukaryotic cells are sophisticated sensors of mechanical forces. Unlike bacteria, which have limited mechanosensory abilities, functioning mainly in osmoregulation, Eukaryotes have additional capabilities including force sensing involved in touch, hearing, and fluid flow. So how did mechanosensing evolve in Eukaryotes? For insights into this question, we turned to marine dinoflagellates, unicellular Eukaryotes that possess a rapid and complex mechanosensing system yet as protists reside near the base of the Eukaryotic tree. The goal of this project was to investigate the relationship between mechanical properties of the dinoflagellate cell and mechanosensitivity, using the intrinsic bioluminescence of marine dinoflagellates as a rapid whole-cell reporter of mechanical stress. We investigated the mechanical properties of the cell, how mechanosensitivity was related to these properties, and the role of the cytoskeleton in determining the mechanical properties of cells and their physiological sensitivity. The tools we used to generated quantified mechanical stimuli included shear flow in a microfluidic device, and atomic force microscopy to measure the elasticity of living cells and apply quantified mechanical stress. By using chemical treatments that selectively disrupted the cytoskeletal architecture of the cells, we investigated the contribution of microtubules and actin filaments to cell stiffness and mechanosensitivity. Finally, we tested dinoflagellate species with different cell morphologies to examine the contribution of rigid peripheral cellular structures.

Cells of the dinoflagellate Lingulodinium polyedra, a species known as the source of red tides in southern California, that were tested in shear flow within a microfluidic device still retained considerable ability to respond to mechanical stimulation despite cytoskeletal disruption, as confirmed by confocal laser scanning microscopy. This finding was independently confirmed using atomic force microscopy with other species, in which controlled forces are directly applied to individual cells. For cells of the dinoflagellate Pyrocystis lunula, cytoskeletal disruption had only a small effect on cell stiffness and mechanosensitivity. As P. lunula possesses a rigid cell wall, we examined the effect of cytoskeleton disruption for the dinoflagellate Noctiluca scintillans, which lacks rigid cell structures. The cell stiffness of N. scintillans, while less than that of P. lunula, was not affected by cytoskeletal disruption. Overall, we conclude that the microtubule and actin filaments of the dinoflagellate cytoskeleton are not major contributors to determining mechanosensitivity, which we speculate is based instead on the characteristics of the cell membrane, which contains mechanosensitive proteins including GTP-binding proteins, and TRP-like and piezo-like ion channels. The structure and function of these mechanosensitive proteins have been evolutionarily conserved in higher organisms including mammals.

As part of the broader impacts component of this project, we developed and implemented a bioluminescence art exhibit called Infinity Cube, highlighting dinoflagellate and other forms of bioluminescence. The exhibit featured video streams of dinoflagellate bioluminescence projected onto a reflective cube; science interpretation including graphics of bioluminescence and luminescent organisms, high magnification video of dinoflagellates, preserved specimens of luminescent animals, a social media component, and most uniquely, haikus to present the science concepts. During the almost 1½ years (from April 2017 to September 2018) that the exhibit was on display at the Birch Aquarium at Scripps, more than half a million visitors toured the facility and more than 60,000 visitors directly interacted with educators positioned in the exhibit.
